image.altText: Man in hat, woman in dress hold hands

items.synopsis: Twenty-four hours after a horror bus crash killed 10 wedding guests, there have been prayers, candles and a guernsey tribute.

title.children: Two victims identified, as tributes pour in after tragic wedding bus crash

image.altText: Fiona Mardling smiling in a portrait, wearing a blue clinic uniform and a stethscope around her neck.

items.synopsis: Nurses outside of hospitals say they are not being used to their full capacity, with one group blaming Medicare rules for holding them back.

title.children: 'I feel very frustrated': Fiona is a highly trained nurse who spends her days changing dressings

image.altText: Bouquets bunch of flowers on the ground.

items.synopsis: A 58-year-old bus driver has been charged over the crash that killed 10 people and left more than 20 injured in the NSW Hunter region on Sunday night.

title.children: Bus driver charged over crash that killed 10 people in Hunter Valley

image.altText: Silvio Berlusconi looks into the distance.

items.synopsis: The controversial politician and media mogul has died in hospital in Milan after suffering from leukaemia for "some time".

title.children: Former Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi dies, aged 86

image.altText: More revelations in the Jeffrey Epstein investigation

items.synopsis: JPMorgan Chase has agreed to pay about $430 million to settle a lawsuit by Jeffrey Epstein's victims who had accused the bank of being the financial conduit that allowed him to continue operating a sex trafficking operation.

title.children: Jeffrey Epstein victims reach $430 million settlement with JPMorgan Chase bank

image.altText: A composite image including the Karen's Diner sign and a notice on the door showing a termination of the lease.

items.synopsis: Viral social media restaurants Karen's Diner close, leaving former workers alleging sexual and physical harassment claims in doubt.

title.children: Karen's Diner employees' concerns remain unresolved as liquidators appointed to multiple restaurants

image.altText: Three flight attendants — a man in a dark suit, and two women wearing red and black dresses — stand in a plane smiling.

items.synopsis: The airline is scrapping its gender-based uniform guidelines — and it's not the first, with many airlines having updated their rules to allow staff to show their authentic selves.

title.children: Qantas to allow flat shoes, make-up and long hair on crew of any gender — but what does this mean for inclusivity?

image.altText: A man with a small moustache and dressed in camo sits inside a military vehicle

items.synopsis: As Ukrainian forces continue their push in and around Bakhmut, soldiers returned from the frontline say the Australian-built armoured personnel carrier is helping keep them alive.

title.children: Returned from the Bakhmut front line, Ukrainian soldiers say Australia's Bushmasters helped them survive

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios stands on a grass court, wearing his cap backwards, and points a finger after winning a tennis match.

items.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios is to make his long-awaited return after seven months sidelined, taking to the grass in Stuttgart in preparation for his return to Wimbledon.

title.children: Nick Kyrgios 'super-excited' to make court comeback on grass in Stuttgart

image.altText: Yasir Al Rumayyan speaks to Dustin Johnson while holding the trophy at a LIV Golf event

items.synopsis: What the PGA Tour-PIF deal shows is that as heinous as some of Saudi Arabia's crimes are, the stakes involved in strategic global alignments are much higher, and the USA is willing to look beyond human rights abuses when necessary, writes Tracey Holmes.

title.children: Terrorism, big business and foreign policy — the reshaping of global golf

image.altText: People stand over a map of the world.

items.synopsis: With only 24 hours in a day, researchers have crunched the numbers and worked out what the average global human day looks like.

title.children: This is what the average human day looks like. How do Australians compare?

image.altText: Three police officers examine the underside of a bus that has turned on its side.

items.synopsis: Forensic and traffic police are piecing together the events of a fatal bus crash in NSW's Hunter Valley, which has claimed the lives of 10 wedding-goers.

title.children: What we know about how a bus carrying more than 30 wedding guests crashed in the NSW Hunter

image.altText: Aerial photo of a block of new-looking houses and a road with farmland around the development.

items.synopsis: The state government faces pressure to abandon a pilot program that allows developers to bypass councils to nominate major housing projects.

title.children: NSW councils condemn 'secret' housing rezoning process for major developments

image.altText: Fire crews stand in front of an overturned bus beside a road.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Bus crash driver to face court today, and a man found dead in a backyard near Brisbane. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The last parliamentary sitting fortnight before the winter break begins today with the government keen to ensure the path of its legislation for the Indigenous Voice referendum. Without a majority in the Senate, the government will need support from the crossbench – but it'll also have to convince Australians — with a new poll (of only 1606 voters) suggesting support has slipped below a majority. The Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians, Malarndirri McCarthy, says she feels excited by what she is hearing from Australians, but admits the Coalition's campaign is "having an impact". "I'm conscious that here on Capital Hill people do like to say all sorts of things, and perhaps without really any care or responsibility," she says. "But when you're on the ground, out there, as I've been, with First Nations people, and see the deep hurt that they've experienced for decades, over policies that should never have occurred, and if they feel they can have a say, that this is something that's important to them. "Then I say to politicians here, this may not matter to you, but it matters to First Nations people on the ground. "And I say to my senators, and my colleagues, all of them, on every side, keep this debate in the next fortnight enormously respectful. "We can do this as a country, in a very dignified, respectable way. So it should be in the debate."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Assistant minister responds to poll showing support for the Voice is dropping

props.alt: A woman with slightly curly hair and large earrings gives a TV interview in front of a Canberra parliament house backdrop

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
The last parliamentary sitting fortnight before the winter break begins today
with the government keen to ensure the path of its legislation for the Indigenous Voice referendum.
Without a majority in the Senate, the government will need support from the crossbench – but it'll also have to convince Australians — with
a new poll (of only 1606 voters) suggesting support has slipped below a majority
The Assistant Minister for Indigenous Australians, Malarndirri McCarthy, says she feels excited by what she is hearing from Australians, but admits the Coalition's campaign is "having an impact".
"I'm conscious that here on Capital Hill people do like to say all sorts of things, and perhaps without really any care or responsibility," she says.

"But when you're on the ground, out there, as I've been, with First Nations people, and see the deep hurt that they've experienced for decades, over policies that should never have occurred, and if they feel they can have a say, that this is something that's important to them.
"Then I say to politicians here, this may not matter to you, but it matters to First Nations people on the ground.
"And I say to my senators, and my colleagues, all of them, on every side, keep this debate in the next fortnight enormously respectful.
"We can do this as a country, in a very dignified, respectable way. So it should be in the debate."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A homicide investigation has been launched after the death of a man in Logan, south of Brisbane. Police say they found the body of a 67-year-old man in the backyard of a home on Redwood Street in the suburb of Marsden early this morning, and arrested a 30-year-old man. A 60-year-old woman who was also home at the time was not hurt. Police say the three people are known to each other. Family and domestic violence support services: If you need help immediately call emergency services on triple-0 1800 Respect National Helpline : 1800 737 732 Women's Crisis Line : 1800 811 811 Men's Referral Service : 1300 766 491 Lifeline : 131 114 Relationships Australia : 1300 364 277
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Man found dead in backyard after alleged domestic violence incident south of Brisbane

children.content: A homicide investigation has been launched after the death of a man in Logan, south of Brisbane.
Police say
they found the body of a 67-year-old man in the backyard of a home
on Redwood Street in the suburb of Marsden early this morning, and arrested a 30-year-old man.
A 60-year-old woman who was also home at the time was not hurt.
Police say the three people are known to each other.
Family and domestic violence support services:
If you need help immediately call emergency services on triple-0
1800 Respect National Helpline
Women's Crisis Line
Men's Referral Service
Lifeline
Relationships Australia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: US comedian and actor Marlon Wayans has had to cancel a show after a spat with a United Airlines employee over carry-on luggage. The Scary Movie star wrote on Instagram that a gate agent told him he had too many bags, and that he would have to check in his luggage rather than carry it on. Wayans, who says his treatment constitutes harassment, reportedly took his ticket, pushed past an employee and tried to board the plane from Denver to Kansas City. He booked a later flight, saying he would rather fly coach on another airline than fly first-class on United. He apologised to his fans in Kansas City for missing a performance. "Sorry KC I'm gonna miss tonight's shows due to a United gate agent who probably hated White Chicks," Wayans says on Twitter, referring to his 2004 movie which also starred his brother Shawn Wayans. Wayans must appear in court in Denver on July 11 on a citation of disturbing the peace.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Comedian Marlon Wayans cancels US show after airline spat

props.alt: A black man in a suit stands in front of a sign which reads 'Marlon'

children.content: (AP: Richard Shotwell/Invision)
US comedian and actor Marlon Wayans has had to cancel a show after a spat with a United Airlines employee over carry-on luggage.
The Scary Movie star wrote on Instagram that
a gate agent told him he had too many bags
, and that he would have to check in his luggage rather than carry it on.
Wayans, who says his treatment constitutes harassment, reportedly took his ticket, pushed past an employee and tried to board the plane from Denver to Kansas City.
He booked a later flight, saying he would rather fly coach on another airline than fly first-class on United.
He apologised to his fans in Kansas City
for missing a performance.
"Sorry KC I'm gonna miss tonight's shows due to a United gate agent who probably hated White Chicks," Wayans says on Twitter, referring to his 2004 movie which also starred his brother Shawn Wayans.
Wayans must appear in court in Denver on July 11 on a citation of disturbing the peace.

image.altText: Blurry screenshots of personal ID documents like passports, and other documents marked "confidential".

title.children: 'You have 3 days': Russian criminals post screenshots of passports to dark web after bond broker data breach

image.altText: A man smiling standing in front of a cool room fridge of lamb

items.synopsis: Farmer Colin Harper was fed up with being a price taker — and not a price maker — when it came to selling his lambs. To solve the problem, the Riverina farmer decided to step away from the saleyards.

title.children: Sick of having lamb prices dictated to him by supermarkets, this farmer went direct to the customer

image.altText: Donald Trump in blue suit and red tie speaking at podium with US flag in the background.

items.synopsis: Former US attorney-general William Barr says Donald Trump is "toast" if allegations that he wilfully retained hundreds of highly classified documents are proven true under Special Counsel Jack Smith's 37-count indictment against the former president.

title.children: Donald Trump's former attorney-general says 'he's toast' if indictment allegations are true

image.altText: A sign outside Banksia Hill Detention Centre with a police officer nearby.

items.synopsis: The WA Department of Justice is accused of intimidating and bullying staff who speak about Western Australia's juvenile detention facilities, including by warning them about possible jail time.

title.children: 'Cease immediately': Leaked email shows warning to Banksia Hill officers over workplace conversations

image.altText: One hand on a laptop's trackpad while another hand holds a credit card

items.synopsis: Fraudulent sites are mimicking real brands, going as far as stealing logos and brand design. Melinda did the checks but they weren't enough — so here are the signs to look out for.

title.children: Fake websites are getting slicker and mimicking real brands. Melinda fell for one and wants others to know the signs

image.altText: An older woman in a light green t-shirt sits on a couch next to a younger woman in a green top.

items.synopsis: Born without a uterus, Prue always wanted children of her own. After trialling different options for a baby, a family friend offered her a transplant.

title.children: A family friend's gift gives Prue the chance to have a baby

image.altText: A woman in a white shirt smiles at the camera.

items.synopsis: Patients will no longer have to travel hundreds of kilometres or pay thousands in up front costs as a bulk-billed care centre opens in the NSW Riverina.

title.children: Cancer patient's travel time cut from four hours to two minutes

image.altText: A young man runs away from the camera on a football field at night kicking a soccer ball. He is wearing a team uniform.

items.synopsis: Australian soccer's governing body is taking a cut from every local bet placed on games at all levels, including amateur suburban competitions.

title.children: 'It's disturbing': This suburban football club had no idea international gamblers could place bets on their games

image.altText: An ASX board shot by John Gunn in Deccember 2022.

items.synopsis: The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq jump to a 13-month high, boosted by tech stocks. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wall Street rallies as investors hope US central bank will pause rate hikes, ASX set to rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets blog. It's been a good night on Wall Street as investors hope the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates on hold this week at 5 to 5.25 per cent. The S & P 500 and the Nasdaq closed at the highest since April last year, with the benchmark index in a bull market. The S & P 500 is up by 21 per cent from its low in October last year. Tech heavyweights drove the market and software firm Oracle hit a record high ahead of its quarterly results. Consumer prices are predicted to have cooled in May and traders see a 76 per cent chance the Fed will pause its rate hikes this week. Grab some coffee and let's go.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US stocks hit highest since April

children.content: Good morning, and welcome to the ABC's Markets blog.
It's been a good night on Wall Street as investors hope the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates on hold this week at 5 to 5.25 per cent.
The S
P 500 and the Nasdaq closed at the highest since April last year, with the benchmark index in a bull market.
The S
P 500 is up by 21 per cent from its low in October last year.
Tech heavyweights drove the market and software firm Oracle hit a record high ahead of its quarterly results.
Consumer prices are predicted to have cooled in May and traders see a 76 per cent chance the Fed will pause its rate hikes this week.
Grab some coffee and let's go.

image.altText: A man speaks into a megaphone surrounded by journalists outside in PNG

items.synopsis: Papua New Guinea's former prime minister, Peter O'Neill, is charged with giving false evidence after a commission of inquiry recommends he be prosecuted.

title.children: Former PNG prime minister Peter O'Neill charged with giving false evidence at inquiry

image.altText: Ben Stokes walks with the sun framing his head

items.synopsis: England have revitalised their Test team — and some would say the entire red-ball form of the sport — with their free hitting, fun loving style under new coach Brendon McCullum. But what is it about Bazball that has been so successful?

title.children: Australia set for first look at England's Bazball revolution

image.altText: Australian banknotes, mostly $50 bills, strewn over a flat surface.

title.children: The ATO's changed the methods you can use to claim tax deductions for working from home

image.altText: A group of soldiers and small frail children covered in blankets on the jungle floor

items.synopsis: The eldest child of the four siblings told her family their mother was alive for four days before she died from injuries in plane crash.

title.children: Rescued child says mother survived for days in jungle after plane crash

image.altText: Composite image of Shellie Morris, Astrid Jorgenson, Tim Winton and Barry Humphries.

items.synopsis: Prominent Australians including author Tim Winton and late comedian Barry Humphries are appointed to the Order of Australia, in the first year women outnumber men on the honours list.

title.children: 'Life's great, I love it': The passionate Australians being honoured this King's Birthday

image.altText: A man in the suit on the left looks happy with himself and a man in the right in a suit looks up up at the gallery

items.synopsis: Transparency and integrity experts criticise the Tasmanian government's reliance on claims of cabinet confidentiality to avoid releasing departmental advice about its controversial plan to build a stadium on Hobart's waterfront.

title.children: Transparency experts slam Tasmanian government secrecy over planned stadium

image.altText: Woman stands next to a white ute, brown boder collie dogs sits in the tray.

image.altText: A marijuna plant.

image.altText: Mayon volcano belches red-hot emissions down it's slope as seen from Legaspi, Albay province.

title.children: Philippines volcano spews lava down slopes in gentle eruption putting thousands on alert
